Developer Test

Faizal Sahebdin

Introduction

This test requires you to demonstrate a range of front-end skills particularly JavaScript, HTML and CSS by building an application as specified in the summary.

Consider this a chance to show of your coding ability. Demonstrate functional, well-commented code with tests.

Summary

Write a simple JavaScript application that reads paragraphs of text input by the user and creates a tabular list of all the words entered. It should also display a count of words, commas and full stops below the table.

The UI

The Table

Requirements
  • The user interface should consist of a textarea, button and results table
  • Account for words and letters only, if the paragraphs contains any numbers then inform the user only words are allowed
  • The application should accept a minimum of 5 words, a maximum of 500 words
  • Treat standalone letters such as `I` and `a` as words
  • Special characters such as (- _ ‘ [ ] { } “ £ $ & % ! : ; \ / ) should either be ignored or treated as part of the word they sit within
  • Commas and full stops should be tallied
  • We are not expecting any server side interactivity or database integration
  • All files required to run the application should be supplied in your delivery
Optional tasks
  • Test that your app works in
    • IE8 - ✖ In progress: still polyfilling
    • IE9 - ✔ Partial: minor styling issues
    • IE10+ ✔
    • Firefox ✔
    • Safari ✔
    • Chrome ✔
  • Make your design responsive, ideally making it mobile and tablet compatible
  • Order columns alphabetically
  • Order rows alphabetically
  • Write a test for your app: e.g. jasmine, qunit, karma
What we are looking for
  • High quality and maintainable code
  • Use of best practice JavaScript techniques
  • Accessible, semantic and valid HTML
  • Well documented and commented code
  • Sensible, separated functionality following the OO paradigms
Notes
  • Written is Vanilla JS
  • Scaffolded using Yeoman
  • UI/design is loosely based on Google's Material Design with a mobile-first approach
  • Normalising with (styles/components/_normalise.scss) from Normalize.css
  • Prefixing during build using Autoprefixr
  • getElementById? Yes, test here: getElementById vs. querySelector
  • Choice of loop? Same as above, good speed, test here: Fastest array loops in Javascript
  • gzipped files served: html (5.7Kb), css (4.5Kb) & js (5.0Kb)
